text: The Epstein-Barr virus latency BamHI-Q promoter is positively regulated by STATs and <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interference with JAK / STAT activation leads to loss of BamHI-Q promoter activity .
In Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) - associated tumors in nonimmunocompromised patients , EBV gene expression is highly restricted .
<extra_id_0> EBV-encoded nuclear antigen (EBNA)-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is expressed , whereas the immunogenic and proliferative EBNAs are not .
This pattern of EBNA expression is generated by usage of the BamHI-Q promoter ( Qp ) .
We have determined that the JAK / STAT pathway positively regulates Qp activity .

In transient - transfection assays , a Qp-CAT reporter was activated by cotransfected <extra_id_0> JAK-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and by treatment of cells with the cytokine <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The ability of Qp to bind signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT ) proteins was directly demonstrated by electrophoretic mobility-shift assay , and mutation of potential STAT - binding sites reduced Qp responsiveness to <extra_id_0> Janus kinase (JAK)-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Consistent with a role for STATs in Qp function , Qp using Burkitt 's lymphoma Rael cells and cultured nasopharyngeal carcinoma ( NPC ) cells contained nuclear STAT protein .
We investigated whether the inability to maintain EBV - positive NPC cell lines in culture was related to Qp activity .

Passaging of the NPC cell line HK666 led to activation of expression of <extra_id_0> BZLF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which encodes <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and loss of Qp function .
Transient expression assays linked <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression to the down-regulation of Qp .
Cotransfection of <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reduced Qp activity in reporter assays .
This negative regulation required <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> DNA - binding activity .

We provide evidence that <extra_id_0> Zta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> up-regulation of <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated interference with JAK / STAT activation of Qp .
The data imply that JAK / STAT signaling has a role in EBV - associated malignancies .
